hints.label: thm-ig-edge-weights-algorithmic
hints.title: Algorithmic Determination of IG Edge Weights
hints.content:
145: :label: thm-ig-edge-weights-algorithmic
146: 
147: **Source:** [13_E_cst_ig_lattice_qft.md § 2.1b, lines 284-345]
148: 
149: For episodes $e_i$ and $e_j$ with temporal overlap period $T_{\text{overlap}} = \{t : e_i, e_j \in \mathcal{A}(t)\}$, the IG edge weight is **algorithmically determined** (not arbitrary):
150: 
151: $$
152: w_{ij} = \int_{T_{\text{overlap}}} P(c_i(t) = j \mid i) \, dt
153: 
154: $$
155: 
156: where $P(c_i(t) = j \mid i)$ is the **companion selection probability** from Chapter 03, Definition 5.7.1:
157: 
158: $$
159: P(c_i(t) = j \mid i) = \frac{\exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,j;t)^2}{2\varepsilon_c^2}\right)}{Z_i(t)}
160: 
161: $$
162: 
163: with:
164: - **Algorithmic distance:** $d_{\text{alg}}(i,j)^2 = \|x_i - x_j\|^2 + \lambda_{\text{alg}} \|v_i - v_j\|^2$
165: - **Cloning interaction range:** $\varepsilon_c > 0$ (algorithm parameter)
166: - **Partition function:** $Z_i(t) = \sum_{l \in \mathcal{A}(t) \setminus \{i\}} \exp(-d_{\text{alg}}(i,l;t)^2 / 2\varepsilon_c^2)$
167: 
168: **Discrete approximation:**
169: 
170: $$
171: w_{ij} \approx \tau \sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{\exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i,j; t_k)^2}{2\varepsilon_c^2}\right)}{Z_i(t_k)}
172: 
173: $$
174: 
175: where $\tau$ is the discrete timestep size and $n$ is the number of timesteps in the overlap period.
176: 
177: **Proof:** See [13_E_cst_ig_lattice_qft.md § 2.1b, lines 316-345] for complete derivation.

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-41
hints.title: Physical Interpretation
hints.content:
183: :class: note
184: 
185: **Source:** [13_E_cst_ig_lattice_qft.md § 2.1b, lines 347-355]
186: 
187: **Sparsity:** For episodes with short overlap or large separation ($d_{\text{alg}} \gg \varepsilon_c$), the exponential factor implies $w_{ij} \approx 0$ (exponential suppression). The IG is **sparse** by construction.
188: 
189: **Euclidean Distance:** The algorithm uses **Euclidean** algorithmic distance $d_{\text{alg}}$, even though the emergent geometry is Riemannian. This is not a bug—as proven in Chapter 13B, Section 3.4, the Euclidean weights automatically discover the Riemannian structure through the QSD equilibrium distribution.

hints.label: prop-ig-spacelike-separation
hints.title: IG Edges Connect Causally Disconnected Events
hints.content:
197: :label: prop-ig-spacelike-separation
198: 
199: **Source:** [13_E_cst_ig_lattice_qft.md § 2.1, lines 259-281]
200: 
201: For any IG edge $e_i \sim e_j$:
202: 
203: $$
204: e_i \not\prec e_j \quad \text{and} \quad e_j \not\prec e_i
205: 
206: $$
207: 
208: (neither is an ancestor of the other in the CST).
209: 
210: **Proof:** By construction, IG edges connect episodes that are **simultaneously alive**:
211: 
212: $$
213: e_i \sim e_j \implies \exists t : e_i, e_j \in \mathcal{A}(t)
214: 
215: $$
216: 
217: If $e_i \prec e_j$, then $t^{\rm d}_i < t^{\rm b}_j$ (child born after parent dies), contradicting simultaneous existence. Similarly, $e_j \prec e_i$ leads to contradiction. Therefore, $e_i$ and $e_j$ are causally independent in the CST. ∎
218: 
219: **Spacelike separation:** For $e_i \sim e_j$, define the interval:
220: 
221: $$
222: \Delta s^2(e_i, e_j) = -c^2 (t_i - t_j)^2 + d_g(\mathbf{x}_i, \mathbf{x}_j)^2 > 0
223: 
224: $$
225: 
226: (positive $\implies$ spacelike).
